Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: The African-American Experience of Race in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will collect social network survey data to analyze the community structure of an American group in Japan. The award will support research to assess how American minorities maintain connections among themselves, form bonds outside the group, and establish bilateral relationships. African-Americans and the Japanese have interacted socially and politically across American and Japanese national borders for over a century, particularly during crucial periods of U.S.-Japan relations and internal national social and political movements. This study will contribute to discussions of American migration and international interaction, as well as interdisciplinary work on global migration, social networks, and minoritization. This project will be conducted under the mentorship of Dr. John G. Russell of Gifu University. As a prominent scholar, whose work focuses of the representation and history of Blacks in Japan, Dr. Russell's contribution to this project will be invaluable. In addition to data on community structure, the researcher will gather interviews and ethnographic data to elaborate and enrich the findings of more quantitative research methods.

Using social network and cultural consensus analyses, this project will outline the structure of the African-Americans' social network in Japan and the ideological barriers that appear within and influence this structure. Ethnographic data will be collected on issues surrounding the reminoritization of this population in a nation that has a national narrative of homogeneity. Cultural consensus analysis will provide access to these boundaries within the community allowing for a richer description of why individuals are connecting, clustering, or distancing from each other in a way that social network data cannot.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study focused on the experiences of African-Americans in Japan as narrated by them in interviews and various forms of media. A significant component of this investigation was social network surveying and analysis, a set of methods designed to collect and display information on social relationships and community structure. Part of the study’s purpose was to explore the potential of social network analysis (SNA) to enrich the ethnographic data collected by interviewing and observing African-Americans in Japan. Beyond exploring the potential of applying mixed methods to the study of this population, this approach allowed the researcher to corroborate observational data against participant derived social network surveys. Using social network analysis and several ethnographic methods, I was able to develop a preliminary map of social connections existing in the Greater Tokyo area. The data collected suggests that the Greater Tokyo Black community, defined in broad terms, has formed several subgroups that maintain distinct characteristics.

Through the support of the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) fellowship, I was able to work with Dr. John G. Russell, an anthropologist at Gifu University. As a long-standing figure in the Japanese research community, Dr. Russell provided excellent guidance for the development and implementation of this project. Additionally, this opportunity allowed for me to strengthen ties with Japanese researchers, as well as graduate students from a variety of backgrounds. The EAPSI has assisted in the building of important international and professional ties for me as an emerging scholar.

This project intends to contribute to migration and minority studies in both the United States and Japan, specifically in the discipline of anthropology. Data collected in this study will be presented at the Japan Black Studies Association’s 64th Annual Conference. Additionally, I intend to present and publish on the material collected during the EAPSI fellowship in the future.
